coredata.dc:title: Microscopic configurations and shape of the atom—atom pair distribution function of liquid chlorine
coredata.dc:creator: De Santis, A.
Gregori, A.
Rocca, D.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The atom—atom pair distribution function is studied in terms of microscopic ordered configurations following a method of analysis quite different from the usual methods of the literature. In the case of two models of liquid chlorine, it is shown that the T-shaped configurations are mainly responsible for the differences in the atom—atom distribution functions. The physical reasons of such differences are also discussed.

Introduction The fluids of simple molecules are usually mo- delled by effective potentials due to isotropic inter- action sites, occasionally improved by multipolar electrostatic interactions. For liquid chlorine, a two- anisotropic-sites potential has been proposed [1,2]. This potential, usually referred to as A2, gives an atom atom pair distribution function gaa(r) with a second peak sharper than the one predicted by the two-centre Lennard Jones (2U) [31 and the 2LJ- plus-quadrupole (2LJQ) [4] potentials. Moreover, these potentials give very different orientational cor- relation functions and Raman spectra since the strength of the molecular interactions decreases in going from the A2 to the 2LJQ and 2LJ potentials [2,5]. The analysis of the ordered microscopic configu- rations has been used to get insight into the effects caused by changes in the potential form. For ex- ample, it is well established that the addition of a point quadrupole to a 2LJ potential destablizes the crossed microscopic configurations X in favour of the T configurations [61. This effect sharpens the first peak of the g~_~(r) and transforms the subse- quent shoulder in a second peak. However, it has also been observed that similar shapes of the ga-a (r) can be obtained from potential models yielding quite dif- ferent microscopic configurations [7]. In this work, we study the role of the microscopic configurations in determining the shape of the g~~(r) in the case of A2 and 2LIQ potentials of liquid chlorine. We will show that several interesting conclusions about the microscopic local order can be derived from the analysis of the shape of the ga-a ( r). 2.
